subnet_calculator.title: Subnet Calculator
subnet_calculator.description: Calculate network, broadcast, and host information for any subnet.

tooltips.network_address: First IP in subnet - identifies the network
tooltips.broadcast_address: Last IP in subnet - sends to all hosts
tooltips.subnet_mask: Defines network vs host portion of IP
tooltips.wildcard_mask: Inverse of subnet mask - used in ACLs
tooltips.total_hosts: All IP addresses in this subnet
tooltips.first_host: First IP address available for devices
tooltips.last_host: Last IP address available for devices

network_address.title: Network Address
network_address.description: The first IP address in a subnet, used to identify the network itself. Hosts cannot be assigned this address as it represents the entire network segment.

broadcast_address.title: Broadcast Address
broadcast_address.description: The last IP address in a subnet, used to send messages to all devices on the network. When a packet is sent to this address, it reaches every host in the subnet.

subnet_mask.title: Subnet Mask
subnet_mask.description: Defines which portion of an IP address represents the network and which represents the host. A mask of /24 means the first 24 bits identify the network.

wildcard_mask.title: Wildcard Mask
wildcard_mask.description: The inverse of a subnet mask, used in access control lists. Where the subnet mask has 1s, the wildcard has 0s, and vice versa.

usable_hosts.title: Usable Hosts
usable_hosts.description: The number of IP addresses available for devices. Always 2 less than total addresses because network and broadcast addresses are reserved.

cidr_notation.title: CIDR Notation
cidr_notation.description: Classless Inter-Domain Routing notation (e.g., /24) indicates how many bits are used for the network portion. Higher numbers mean smaller subnets with fewer hosts.

tips.title: Pro Tips
tips.plan_growth: Plan for Growth: Choose subnet sizes that accommodate future expansion
tips.binary_understanding: Binary Understanding: Learning binary helps understand how subnetting works
tips.common_sizes: Common Sizes: /24 (254 hosts), /25 (126 hosts), /26 (62 hosts), /30 (2 hosts for point-to-point)
tips.private_networks: Private Networks: Use RFC 1918 addresses (10.x.x.x, 172.16-31.x.x, 192.168.x.x) for internal networks

tooltips.subnetMask: IPv6 subnet mask showing network portion (compressed format)
tooltips.addressRange: First and last assignable addresses in the subnet
tooltips.assignableAddresses: Number of addresses available for host assignment (excluding network/broadcast concepts)
tooltips.reverseDns: PTR record zone for reverse DNS lookups
tooltips.binaryRepresentation: 128-bit binary representation showing network (1) and host (0) bits

about.title: About RP Records
about.description: RP (Responsible Person) records identify the responsible person for a domain or host. They specify both a mailbox (encoded as a domain name) and optionally point to a TXT record with additional contact information. This allows automated discovery of administrative contacts.

ipv4.broadcastAddress: This appears to be a broadcast address (host portion is all 1s)

ipv6.documentationAddress: This is a documentation address (not for production use)

howToTell.title: How to Tell if an IP Address is Valid
howToTell.description: Valid IP addresses follow specific rules. For IPv4, you need exactly four numbers (0-255) separated by dots, like 192.168.1.1. For IPv6, you need eight groups of hex digits separated by colons, though you can compress consecutive zeros with :: (like 2001:db8::1). The validator checks these rules and tells you exactly what's wrong when something doesn't match.

whatHappens.title: What Happens When Addresses Are Invalid
whatHappens.description: Invalid IP addresses cause real problems. Your router might reject them, network connections fail, or software crashes. Common mistakes include typos like "192.168.1.256" (256 is too big), missing parts like "192.168.1", or extra zeros like "192.168.01.01". This tool catches these errors before they break your network setup.

whyWarnings.title: Why Some Addresses Have Warnings
whyWarnings.description: Some valid addresses come with warnings because they have special meanings. For example, addresses ending in .0 are usually network addresses, and ones ending in .255 are broadcast addresses. Private addresses like 192.168.x.x won't work on the internet. The tool explains what each address type means so you know if it's right for your use case.

descriptions.serviceConstraint: Service Certificate Constraint - Certificate must match the one in the TLSA record

descriptions.fullCert: Full Certificate - Use the entire certificate
descriptions.spki: Subject Public Key Info - Use only the public key portion (recommended)

matching.label: Matching Type
matching.tooltip: How to process the certificate data

descriptions.exact: Exact Match - Use the certificate/key data as-is (not recommended)
descriptions.sha256: SHA-256 Hash - Use SHA-256 hash of the certificate/key (recommended)
descriptions.sha512: SHA-512 Hash - Use SHA-512 hash of the certificate/key

output.title: Generated TLSA Record

validation.title: Validation

errors.hexOnly: Hash must contain only hexadecimal characters

warnings.pemFormat: Certificate should be in PEM format
warnings.sha256Length: SHA-256 hash should be exactly 64 hexadecimal characters
warnings.sha512Length: SHA-512 hash should be exactly 128 hexadecimal characters
warnings.usageTypes02: Usage types 0 and 2 require careful CA certificate management
warnings.selectorFull: Full certificate selector (0) is less flexible than SPKI selector (1)
warnings.exactMatch: Exact match (0) is not recommended - use SHA-256 (1) or SHA-512 (2)

tips.usage3: Use usage type 3 (Domain-Issued Certificate) for most scenarios
tips.selectorSpki: Prefer selector 1 (SPKI) over selector 0 (full certificate) for flexibility
tips.hashTypes: Use SHA-256 (1) or SHA-512 (2) matching types, avoid exact match (0)
tips.multipleCerts: Pin multiple certificates to avoid service disruption during certificate rotation

edns_size_estimator.title: EDNS Size Estimator
edns_size_estimator.subtitle: Estimate DNS message size and UDP fragmentation risk with EDNS buffer recommendations

sizeEstimation.title: Size Estimation:
sizeEstimation.description: Calculate total DNS message size including headers and record data.

fragmentationRisk.title: Fragmentation Risk:
fragmentationRisk.description: Assess likelihood of UDP packet fragmentation and delivery issues.

ednsRecommendations.title: EDNS Recommendations:
ednsRecommendations.description: Get buffer size recommendations for optimal DNS performance.

large.name: Large Response
large.description: Many A records causing fragmentation risk

includeQuery.label: Include query section in estimate
includeQuery.tooltip: Include the DNS query section in size calculations. Queries add ~20-50 bytes depending on name length.

queryName.label: Query Name
queryName.tooltip: The domain name being queried. Longer names result in larger message sizes.

queryType.label: Query Type
queryType.tooltip: The type of DNS record being requested (A, AAAA, MX, etc.).

records.title: Response Records
records.empty: No records added. Click "Add Record" to start building your DNS response.

results.title: Size Analysis

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.tcp: Consider using TCP for queries expecting large responses
recommendations.fragment: Some networks may fragment packets - monitor delivery success
recommendations.edns0: EDNS0 support required - advertise appropriate buffer size

udpLimitations.title: UDP Limitations
udpLimitations.description: Classic DNS over UDP is limited to 512 bytes. Larger responses require EDNS0 extension to advertise bigger buffer sizes. Without EDNS0, servers must truncate responses.

fragmentationIssues.title: Fragmentation Issues
fragmentationIssues.description: UDP packets larger than ~1232 bytes may be fragmented by network devices. Fragmented packets are more likely to be dropped, causing DNS resolution failures.

ednsBufferSizes.title: EDNS Buffer Sizes
ednsBufferSizes.description: Common EDNS buffer sizes are 1232, 4096, and 8192 bytes. Larger buffers allow bigger responses but increase fragmentation risk. Choose based on your network environment.

optimizationStrategies.title: Optimization Strategies
optimizationStrategies.description: Minimize record sizes with shorter names and values. Use separate queries for large responses. Consider TCP for consistently large responses like DNSSEC-signed zones.

excellentCoverage.title: Excellent Coverage!
excellentCoverage.description: Your reverse DNS coverage is excellent with {{percentage}}% completeness.

help.ptrRecords: PTR records: One per line, proper format

ptrCoverage.title: PTR Coverage Planning
ptrCoverage.description: PTR coverage analysis helps identify gaps in reverse DNS configuration. Complete coverage ensures all IPs in your network blocks have proper reverse DNS entries for troubleshooting and compliance requirements.

namingPattern.title: Naming Pattern Validation
namingPattern.description: Use regex patterns to enforce consistent hostname naming conventions. Patterns like .*\.corp\.example\.com\.$ ensure all PTR records point to properly formatted hostnames within your domain structure.

commonIssues.title: Common PTR Issues
commonIssues.description: Missing PTRs can cause mail delivery problems and failed reverse lookups. Extra PTRs may indicate outdated records or configuration drift. Regular PTR sweeps help maintain DNS hygiene and network documentation accuracy.

remediation.title: Remediation Best Practices
remediation.description: Create missing PTRs in batches, verify forward/reverse consistency (A/AAAA records), and establish monitoring to detect future gaps. Use descriptive hostnames that include network or service information for easier troubleshooting.
